children.name: wield
children.definition: /wiːld/  to hold a weapon such as a knife or stick and wave it around so that people can see that you are going to use it: cầm, mang, nắm
examples: The rioters faced police who were wielding clubs and batons.
knife-wielding/gun-wielding/sword-wielding etc
Home was a cramped two rooms in a street where gun-wielding criminals walked.

children.name: brandish
children.definition: to hold sth such as a gun, knife, or stick so that people can see it, especially while threatening them: khua, vung
examples: A man brandishing a gun had threatened staff and customers at a local bank.
Four horsemen dashed up at full gallop, shouting and brandishing their weapons.

children.name: grasp at
children.definition: clutch/alsograsp for to take sth in your hand, especially when it is very difficult to do this: vồ lấy, bám lấy
examples: ▪ I clutched at my mother’s arm to keep from falling.
▪ The climber grasped at a small hold just above him.

children.name: take hold of
children.definition: catch/get/grab/ sth/sbto start holding something or someone:
examples: He took hold of one end of the carpet and tugged.
I just managed to grab hold of Lucy before she fell in the pool.
I took hold of the handle and pulled as hard as I could.
Quickly – try and get hold of that frog!
▪ I took hold of the handle and pulled as hard as I could.
▪ Sheila fished in her handbag until she got hold of her keys.
▪ The baby got a hold of her beads and broke the string.

children.name: to hold sth and turn it around in your hands
handle
children.definition: /ˈhændl/  to hold something and turn it around in your hands, for example to examine it or use it: giữ, cầm, sử dụng
examples: ▪ Please do not handle the fruit and vegetables.
▪ This violin is very old and valuable and must be handled carefully.
handleverbTOUCH
[ T ] to pick something up and touch, hold or move it with your hands
Always wash your hands before handling food.
Please don't handle the vases - they're very fragile.

children.name: fiddle with
children.definition: /ˈfɪdl wɪð/  to hold something small and keep turning it around in your hands, especially because you are nervous or bored: đùa nghịch
examples: ▪ Martina was fiddling nervously with her pen.
▪ Stop fiddling with the remote control!

children.name: play with
children.definition: /ˈpleɪ wɪð/  to hold something in your hands and turn it around continuously for no reason: đùa giỡn với
examples: ▪ She played with the red roses on the table as she talked.
▪ Is it worth reading to our kids when they’re busy playing with their hair or their teddy bears? Yes.

children.name: fumble with
children.definition: /ˈfʌmbəl wɪð/  to hold something with your fingers or in your hand, trying to move it in some way, but doing it carelessly or with difficulty: vụng về
examples: ▪ She could hear someone fumbling with the handle of her door.
▪ I fumbled drunkenly with the keys, dropping them to the floor.
▪ He stood before them, his eyes lowered, fumbling with his hat.

children.name: hold
children.definition: the action of holding sth with your handsSYN grip
examples: hold on
She released hertight hold onthe dog.
Hetightenedhishold, refusing to let her go.
Make sure youkeep hold ofmy hand when we cross the road.
Itook hold ofher hand and gently led her away.
Grab hold ofthe rope and pull yourself up.
a tight/firm holdRose had a tight hold of her hand.
tighten your holdMaria winced as Luke tightened his hold on her fingers.
loosen/relax your holdLaughing, he loosened his hold until she could pull her arms free.
release your hold(= stop holding something )As soon as his fingers released their hold, Robyn turned and ran.
keep hold of something(= hold something without letting go )I had to run to keep hold of the leather strap.
get/take hold of something(= start holding something )Wallace took hold of Fred’s jacket and pulled him roughly backwards.
catch/grab/seize etc hold of something(= start holding something quickly and firmly )She grabbed hold of the letter and tore it open.
have hold of something(= be holding something )Nathan had hold of her hand again.

children.name: grasp
children.definition: the way you hold something tightly, especially a part of someone’s body, in order to keep them close to you: cầm lấy, nắm lấy
examples: She tried to escape Moore’s grasp but he was too strong for her.
He shook my hand with a very firm grasp.
tighten your graspgrasp something more tightly nắm chặt, cầm chặt
Helen tightened her grasp on my collar and shouted ‘Don’t fool around with me, Mickey!’

children.name: grip
children.definition: the way you hold something tightly, or your ability to do this :
examples: Hold the microphone in afirm gripand keep it still.
She felt her wrist caught in avice-like grip.
Don’tloosenyourgripon the rope or you’ll fall.
Hereleasedhisgripand stepped back.
a firm/tight gripThe streets were crowded and she kept a tight grip on her bag.
a strong gripMaggie took the boy's arm in a strong grip.
a good grip(= a grip with which you can keep hold of something )The rocks were wet and slippery and it was difficult to get a good grip.
an iron/vice-like grip(= a very strong grip )Victor took hold of her wrist in an iron grip.
have a gripYou need to have a good grip on your tennis racket.
get a grip(= hold something that is hard to hold firmly )I got a good grip on the rope and pulled myself up.
take a gripMitch took a firm grip on her arm.
tighten your grip/your grip tightens(= hold something more tightly )She tightened her grip on her son’s hand.
loosen/relax your grip(= hold something less tightly )Lee loosened his grip on the dog’s collar.
release your grip(= let go of something )The guard released his grip on the prisoner and pushed him into the cell.
lose your grip(= accidentally let go of something )He shoved Higgins out of the way without losing his grip on the gun.

children.name: drop
children.definition: /drɒpǁdrɑːp/  to stop holding somethingsuddenly, especially by accident, so that it falls to the ground:
examples: đánh rơi
▪ I dropped my sunglasses and they broke.
▪ As soon as she saw him she dropped her suitcases and ran towards him.

children.name: let go
children.definition: /ˌlet ˈgəʊ/  to stop holding something or someone:
examples: bỏ ra
▪ Let go! You’re hurting me.
let go of bỏ cái gì ra
▪ She wouldn’t let go of the letter.
▪ At the end of the fair, the school let go of hundreds of balloons.

children.name: release
children.definition: /rɪˈliːs/  especially written to stop holding something, especially someone’s hand, wrist, arm etc: thả
examples: ▪ He took hold of my hand but then released it again quickly.

children.name: clutch
children.definition: to hold sth tightly, especially because you do not want to drop or lose it, usually in fear, worry, or pain: nắm chặt, túm chặt
examples: A businessman hurried past, clutching his briefcase.
The little girl clutched onto his hand.
Silent and pale, she clutched (onto) her mother's hand.
Clutching the money to his chest, he hurried to the bank.
He collapsed, clutching his stomach.
‘Ah!’ he cried, clutching his stomach.
A group of tourists stood clutching their phrase books.

children.name: grip
children.definition: /grɪp/  to hold something tightly, by pressing your fingers very hard against it: nắm chặt
examples: ▪ David suddenly gripped my arm and pulled me away from the road.
▪ His knuckles whitened as he gripped the microphone.
I gripped the rail and tried not to look down.
grip something tightly/firmly
The woman moved closer to Beth, gripping her arm tightly.
▪ She found his hand and gripped it tightly.

children.name: hold on
children.definition: / hang on  to put your hand around something and hold it tightly, in order to stop yourself from falling or from losing what you are holding: nắm chặt, bám chặt (khỏi ngã)
examples: ▪ We’re coming up to a bumpy bit - you’d better hold on!
▪ Just hang on as best you can and I’ll try and get some help.
hold/hang on to sth
▪ Mother’s not strong. She can’t walk without holding on to someone’s arm.
▪ People stood hanging on to the overhead straps of the swaying subway car.
He hung on to the rail at the back of the motorbike.|Hang on tight!
hold on tight
▪ As the roller coaster turned upside down I shut my eyes and held on tight.
▪ He inched across the roof, hanging on as best he could.

children.name: cling to
children.definition: to hold on to someone or something very tightly for comfort or support: bám lấy
examples: ▪ The baby monkey clings to its mother’s back until it can climb by itself.
▪ Many children will cling to a soft blanket or toy as a substitute for their mother at night.
▪ Rescue workers saved a 9-year-old boy who was clinging to rocks after he was swept into the ocean by the tide.

children.name: clasp
children.definition: writtento hold sb/sth tightly, closing your fingers or arms around them : nắm chặt
examples: She was clasping a bunch of small summer flowers.
He clasped her in his arms and kissed her.
Sally ran out of the house, clasping her schoolbooks to her chest.
A little girl stood clasping her mother’s hand.

children.name: to have sth in your hand
in your hand U
children.definition: in your hand if sth is in your hand, you are holding it
examples: What’s that in your hand?
He arrived at the door with an enormous bouquet of flowers in one hand and a bottle of champagne in the other.
in each hand
Theo walked across the yard with a pail in each hand.

children.name: take
children.definition: to get hold of sth in your hands :
examples: Let me take your coat.
Can you take this package while I get my wallet?
A nurse took her arm and led her to a chair.
take somebody/something in/by something
Emily took me by the hand and led me into the garden.
I just wanted to take him in my arms.

children.name: hold
children.definition: /həʊld/  nắm, cầm, giơ
examples: ▪ I held the money tightly in my hand.
▪ In the photograph there was a small boy holding a flag.
▪ A smiling woman holding a can of beer came over to us.
hold up [M]hold something high in the air
▪ What a lovely picture! Hold it up so everyone can see it.
hold something out/hold out something giơ cái gì ra
hold something towards someone, especially to offer it to them
▪ I took a glass of champagne from the tray the waiter held out.
hold sb’s hand[] to hold someone’s hand, especially to comfort them or to make them feel safe:
▪ Hold Mummy’s hand -- there’s a good girl.
▪ Andrew sat next to Jane and held her hand.
▪ He held her hand tightly and led her across the street.
hold handsif two or more people hold hands, they hold each other’s hands
▪ She saw Kurt and Eileen coming back from the beach, kissing and holding hands.
▪ Then we all sat in a circle and held hands.

children.name: grasp
children.definition: writtento take hold of sth firmly, especially in a determined way : túm lấy, nắm lấy
examples: She grasped the lowest branch and pulled herself up into the tree.
I grasped his arm firmly and led him away.
Alan grasped the handle and pulled it.

children.name: keep hold of U
children.definition: keep hold of somethingto continue to hold something :Greg was struggling to keep hold of the dog.|She tried to take her hand away but he kept hold of it.

children.name: hand in hand
children.definition: tay trong tay; nắm tay nhau
examples: holding each other's hand
_I saw them walking hand in hand through town the other day.

children.name: sb's clutches
children.definition: sb'sclutcheshumorous
examples: [ plural ]the control of someone
_Heis in/hasfallen intothe clutchesofthat woman.

children.name: arm in arm
children.definition: khoác tay nhau
examples: When two people are arm in arm, they both have one arm bent at theelbowand passing around and supporting, or being supported by, the arm of the other person
_We walked arm in arm along the river bank.

children.name: hold on
children.definition: tosthphrasal verb
examples: to hold something or someone firmly with your hands or your arms
_Hold onto the rope and don't let go.

children.name: handle
children.definition: nounPART
examples: a part of an object designed for holding, moving or carrying the object easily
_a door handle
_the handle on a suitcase
_I can't pick the kettle up - the handle's too hot.
_Sheturnedthe handle and slowly opened the door.
handheld/ ˌhændˈheld /adjective[ before noun ] B1
B1 describes something that has been designed so that it can be held and used easily with one or two hands:
a handheld computer/device
